div1.p: Robert Carter records his suffering with gout, the work being done on his plantations, the prevailing winds and other weather, visitors he received including members of his family, family weddings and births, trips to Williamsburg and the sums he spent while there, the death and funeral of Governor Hugh Drysdale and his assumption of the post of acting governor of the colony, arrival of ships with goods and letters from Britain, movement of tobacco and other crops from his outlying farms on his sloops, the loading of tobacco on ships bound for Britain, and frequent trips to his farms and mill.

div1.head: Robert Carter Diary, 1726

name.add: [Kept at "Corotoman" on the Rappahannock River, Lancaster County, Virginia]

div1.p:
Janry 1 [1726] I went to Captn Lawrence Store very cold Stood a
great while on the Sand eat heartily bread & Cheese drank
a bottle Soham 2 or 3 glasses wt wine began to be
lame I came home
2d rise very well was Lame when I came out of my
Coach recd the Com[ission?] grew lamer the Gout in my
left foot had an uneasier night rise twice my
Pain in my left foot somewhat better drank water had a
pretty good Night
3d rise easie a little Lame eat no breakfast but
Coffee eat Venison drank some wine Soham
afterwd water in the Night more uneasie the
day before my Goods from Lawrence Landed
4 rise pretty well eat nothing drank Coffee Robin
his wife [and her mother] E[lizabeth] Churchil came home brot my Lettrs
from Keiling & Cobb eat stewd Chicken Turkey drank
wine So ham had a very uneasier night got n[ot]
to sleep till neer 4 slept till allmost 9 rise pr[etty] [well]
but Lame
5 drank Coffee eat nothing mr Stepto here & [r ...]
Eat Peas drank Water some So ham sat up late had a ni[...]
rise twice
6 smart frost W[ind] NW clear had an easie day grow w[...]
Eat a little 12th Cake set up till 12 drank 3 or 4 Gla[sses wine]
had a uneasie Night sharp weather wind Blows [hard?]
sent Cha Coachman to Peanketank [River ...]
Janry 8th 1725/6
my Goods from Keiling came this morning
mr McNeal Captn McCrag came here I drank Coffee in
the morning Eat Peas stewd Chick [sic] drank sevl Glasses wine
at Night drank pt of a bottle Cydr my foot sweld grow very
lame had a bad Night can hardly walk had a Sorer pain
above my Ancle
8 very lame can hardly hobble rise at Sunrise W[ind] SW last
Night Lawrence men brot my sloop home had my flat into
Corotoman Captn Keeling here wee plaid till 11 my
Ancle very much sweld & very stiff had a bad night
9 rise pretty Easie but so lame could not go to Church
continued all day my Ancle & toe sweld at night very
Painfull went to bed slept till neer one got upon abun
dance of pain set up an hour slept till 1/2 an hour aftr
3 in a great deal of pain fell a sleep again slept till
seven easie swelling a little abated rise after 8
10 very lame was forct to get a gout slipper & larger
Stocking can hardly Set my foot to the ground
hoble abt wth a Crutch drank Coffee in the morning Saing
came here Eat fre[sh] barley drank Some Whay went to
bed after 10 slept till five my right foot Complains
my left Contiues very full of pain & sweld my
pain cheifly above my Ankle
11 a rainey morning W[ind] at NE. pretty warm a good
Season I was pretty easie all this [day] drank Coffee
at 2 Clock eat a ps plumb Cake at dinner Eat a
little Barley that was very much heightnd
with wine &c drank a great deal of Sack
Whey playd wth Savage my foot very mu[ch]
sweld went to bed in a great deal of
pain from 12 to 3 was upon a rack wth
great difficulty got to the fire after 3
fell asleep Slept til 8 W[ind] came to NW
12 was pretty easie all this day T Edwds
C Grimes came here playd till almost
12 Clock my foot very much swelled was
taken wth a pain [in] my Side held me 2 hour
could not Sleep usd hot Cloths it removd in
to my Stomach very oppressive to my
breath Eat homini this day drank some Sy
der & water & some water after
I paid of Monsieur Arigo today his ball
[a]nce was 14/5/3 I gave him 19£ Cash the
[rema]ind[e]r for his Journey to Phyladelphia
[We?] parted very easily I took Physick at 5
[Wind at] NW blew hard rise at 9 pretty Eas[ie]
[free?] of the Pain in my Side
Janry 17256
14 I continue pretty easie all day my
foot very much sweld had an untowd Night
a pain above my right Ancle mr MacNeal
had six hogs 6 bushell of Peas Salt I eat
for my dinnr Peas a wing of a Chicken 1/2 doz
fryd Oysters had a very uneasie Night
15 rose very much out of Ordr headach Qua
ling the Pain in my right Ancle much
less my swelling in my right foot abated
I sent a Warrt to Parson Scott for 3000
Acres of Land in K[ing] G[eorge] & Stafford Yesterday
gave a lease to Jno Bell for 150 Acres
L[ewis] Burwells Land after drinking Coffee
was very easier rain in the morning after
a fine warm calm Sunshine day Eat
Chocolate drank sevl Cydr Night very un[easie?]
Swelling continued mr Lee here playd
till 11 Stagg here
16 Sunday Snowd did not go to Church
P[hilip] Smith came home sat till 11 very
Easie swelling continues rise in the
Night Eat nothing but Chocolate &
Toast & Buttr
17 Swelling abated in the morning d
rank Coffee Eat Tost Buttr drink small
beer Edwds 2 Fleets Turvervile wen[t]
in my boat to the Oyer & Terminer [court]
recd Lettrs from Mr.Stark 24 Oct dates
Snowd Yesterday hard frost last Nigh[t]
cold this morning W[ind] NW not hard
W[illiam] Strother came here sat up till 11 drank small beer
had an easier Night swelling abates dailey
18 rainey Fleets went away early, raind Edwds Smith
went away writ to Savage Carter Dade Linton Eat
Chocolate Peas drank small beer sat up till 11
Easie slept well
19 Signd Cnditions wth Strother he went away
gave him my Noat for his Salary pd him 5[£?]
for Rd Haynes cold raw cloudy day Changd [...]
Gouty Slipper swelling very little
20 Maj Eskridg came here Snow cloudy W[ind] West [...]
& Garland here Signd Conditions wth [Richard] Meeks Setled Accots
21 Captn Morrison came here wth Coll Pages [boy?]
22 Eskridg & Morrison here writ fo[r ...]
Perry sent to my Daughter [...]
Jan 20 1725 [1726]
My Son Robert Negros went away
21 Meeks went away cold cloudy Snowy weather
22 bittr Snowy Weather W[ind ]N & to the eastwd
23 Sunday Eskridg went away bittr frosty cloud[y]
weather my Family with Captn Morrison went
to Church no body there continues cloudy hard
frost W[ind] N
24 Sent Coll Page boy over the river frosty cloudy
calm kild the last of my hogs my Swelling quite
gon I walk strong at [word omitted] Dr Edgar came here
25 Cloudy frosty calm W[ind] NW
26 continues cloudy cold frosty W[ind] W
I signd H[enry] Lees Deed also Murphews
Escht Warrt Matty had a pd Coffee
this day is to last 21 days
27 last night my Sloop went away for
mr Hamiltons Goods to Wiccomoco
a calm cool morning w[in]d So[uth] writ to
Major Eskridge Meeks sent away Mur
phews Warrt of Escht H Lees Deed
28 fine frosty Morning walkt in my Sliprs
to the Old house W[ind] SoE fresh Gale Captn
Morrison went away
Tully tells me Captn Lawrence had 380 foot
of Plank Denis & T[homas] West had [word omitted] Peter
brot home my runaway Captn Woodward arri
vd & came ashore with Bisco brot my Lrs
from Captn Hyde & Landon
29 a fine day W[ind] W began Falconars
Tea Mat[ty] had 1/2 lb Sent mrs Seaton 3 pisto[les]
weighd 3/5/7 1/2 the ball[ance] of her Ferry
Accot:
30 I went to Church first time after my Gout
fryday last 28 W[illiam] Waugh found dead neer
the road coming home from Captn Pin
kards
31 a very cold day W[ind] NW I read Turnrs
Lettrs abt an Escheat
[Fe]br 1 W[ind] W cold clear came to SW warmr
2 W[ind] SE weather variable came to SE
4 Sloop [went] to Urbanna
[Captain H]ale arrivd I went aboard bot 9 Ser[vants?]
[I am] to pay 2,000 for Tradesmen 3 15£ for
[...] Capt Lawrence here
Febry 4 1725 [1726]
Portion of 1725[26] diary page
Lawrence had my Sloop out of the
Creek had a new Cable new Sailes new
Hall[iar]ds Takle &c
Daughter Page sent me 2 pols [sic] butter
by Peter Robin & his wife went yesterd[ay]
to mr Edwds Captn Woodward removd
to Corotoman
mr Stag came abt 1 Clock Charles
bad wth the tooth Ach Sam brot home
my horse last Night & Lettrs from Meeks &c
5 my Son mr Stag went aboard Woodwd
to tast some wine for mr Wormeley
came back Coll Grimes wth them
6 my flat set them over [the river] very cold
W[ind] N Doctor Edgar here my two Ne
gros from Ragged point went aw[ay]
Saturday wth Dumeries their Overseer
Monday morn Tully came here
7 began to how a ps Ground for a Nur
sery Edgar had 15s
James Bryan had a Noat for a bushel
Salt on meeks Tully went abt pun
cheons my Carts came home Bunting
did not work till 10 Clock Winder makes
sorry Weeding hoes Birch hath pretended
Sickness 2 daies frost left his work
at Noon has cut his Shin
mr Ja[mes] Reid here.
9 was at Court Coll Tarpley promist to pay me
my Tobo in these parts
10th at Night Sawney came here with Lettrs
by the Burwell
11 I write to Coll Page sent him back the UB Jnos [sic]
Doctor Edgar had 16s & 5 before
14 I delivd mr Rd Lee Shapleys Protest £5: [...]
2 gall rum 2 lb Sugr to Wm Martin for mrs Cook['s]
funeral went aboard Woodwd Choice his win[e ...]
got home abt 9 cold SE wind
15 gave my Son Charles 1 pistole [...]
30s Cash his mild 1/2 Crown [...]
Febry 1725/6
15 gave out 1lb Coffee to begin too morr[ow]
1/2 lb Tea, my Son Charles goes to York
17 I send Captn Carter 6 1/2 Gall rum 6 lb Sugr
I gave out to Gumby 3 brod Chessels to frost 1 bro[ad]
Chessel 1 Scribing ditto, fine weather W[ind] N Gees flock
together mightily very Noisy first Lamb the
12th of the month 1 yeo brot 2 awhile & a black
I go to measure the Corn first time since
W[illiam] Waughs death the 28th he measured the
Corn the Tuesday before the 25th I measured
Just 12 barrels Indian Corn had got to the [word omitted]
17th abt 2 Clock & 3 pecks of Wheat from the
Mill I went to the Office Connrs has not yet
finisht prising 1 has not Top to fill another
must fill it up wth his 2ds I have ordr him to
mark it I saw his Mare hankering abt the
Qrs hath no Calves
Signd Conditions with Tully he hath
don the Puncheons 2,000 & Odd goes Away
to Blough Point gave a Warrt to And Hutcheson for
Land on Solsbury plain runn mrs You
ng Lame sevl daies never comes out
of her Chamber
And Hutcheson brings me a Lettr abt some Land from
Meeks I send him no Warrt as yett writ him the
reason fine calm weather
19 Sam Jones brings me a Bass Has a bottle
rum ows me another Bass
Tho Seddon comes from Stafford abt Lan[d]
12 Lambs this day six alreadie dead
foggy rainy morn very warm mrs
Young keeps her Chamber
21 mrs Young abroad, a cool day W[ind] E I went to H
Kellys drawd his Tobo found it basely handled
corrected him for it he promist to pick out the
bad reckons upon 4 prisd hds came home
[in] the Night found mr Harrison & his wife
[at] my house
[several?] Gent came here I writ Strother Savage
Bell [this?] day wind N Alice Phillis came
[Letter fr]om Henry Hickes came Complains
[...]brot [this?] because he will not
[...] my [...]
Febry 24 1725/6
Sent away by Newgent 3 Deeds to Capt
Strother 13 do to mr Ja Carter
Newgent had 6/3 of me—a fine day
I went to the Store wth mr Harrison & Robin
my sloop wth Gregory came from mr
McNeal this night
25 hasy morn W[ind] SW cold dry 23 lambs
Feb 4th at Night Gregory delivd mr Hamilton['s]
Goods 5th Went into mr McNeals Employ
Two days Tho Frost hat[th] bin upon his ow[n]
Inventions did no work lay out all nigh[t]
no body knew where he was gon
mr Stagg did not come this time
28 my Sloop came from Captn Lawrenc[e]
goes into Captn Keilings Employ
my Three Ser[vants] Sent away wth the Sloop
March 1st Cornelius McGuire Hen Can[t]
Robt Pellit a rainy day I went to Cook['s]
apraisement had done before I came
carried a gall rum Sugr Lime Jui[ce]
1 qt wine spent it & left it all there
2 Signd deeds with Rust for his Land on
Occaquan write to Coll Mason Mary
Sheild Turberbile Eskridge Carter
W[ind] SE fine day raind all night
3 Cloudy W[ind] NW Captn [word omitted] Sent my Goods home my
Servt Talent discovd to me his Marriage I gave to
Cants men a bottle rum had an uneasier Nigh[t]
have bin very much opprest these 3 days
took Andersons Pills this morning in the Night
a humour falls on my Eyes genly with the head
Ach cant Sleep above 4 or 5 hours in 24
4 gave a Noat to Tho Heneag on Accot of Jno Tully to
Captn Carter for six pound
Coll Ball &c here Gregory dispatcht away
first for Captn Lawrence then to Nomini
had a very uneasie Night went not to Sleep til [...]
5 a fine day calm I sent per Gregory 29 gall r[um]
to mr Meeks on his own Accot the Secretary & [family?] came he[re]
7 Came here mr Turbervile here Collo Lomax [here]
8 mr Harrison went away my Pinna[ce takes?]
them down to mr Churchill I le[nt?]
Morgan 40 Shillings [...]ill[...]
March 8 1725/6
my Daughter Mary went away with
her Sistr Harrison I gave Mary 20s I
gave my Daughtr Harrison 2 guineas
for her Daughtrs
9 Coll Lomax came went to Machens in
my Barge a rainy day I went to Court
in my Barge my Sons with me wee d
ind at Pines on Woodwds
entertainmt
my Servts Rd Talent Eliz his wife Artr
Neal Charle [sic] Sulwan bound for six yrs
I became paymt to McNeal for Den
lavy 20£ Sterling Dunlavy confest a
Judgment to me 40£ on condition
on payments the sd 20£ with Interest in 18
months his Son as a further Security bo
und to me as a furthr Security for
2 years Service
Tho Wills servt Confest himself no Gar
dinr the court adjudged him to have
no Wages Wills himself ownd before
the Court the thought he had no right
to Wages.
10 a rainey night W[ind] Shifted to NW
a cloudy raw morning Captn Aug
Washinton here writ to Coll Lomax my
Thots of their difference writ to Savage abt it
11 Coll Grimes came here lent my flatt to Den
lavy to fetch his things over
Jack Ashley here settled An Accot gave him
a Noat to the Store he went away the 12th
writ to Strother Major Robinson
14 Coll Page had 10 bushels Salt Captn Bow
man came in had 10 Weeks Passage
my wine came ashore
mr Rd Lee had Russels Noat on Jno Hud[na]
ll for 2070 lb Tobo indorst W Strother to put
[...] the hands of Perry or Fallin to rece
[...]ttles sent t[o Ma]jr Robinson
March 17 1725/6
Coll Page my Son &c went away Robin went wth
them the Smith went with them my boy
George went for the Colledg Garton brot me a
Bass Coll Grimes went away has my Ordrs
on Travers Downmn for 1990 lb Tobo.
Garton had a qt rum a pr Shoos he ows me anotr
Bass I gave Geo 5S mild 1/2 Crown to Mann
18 went to Denis staked out an Orchard
came home in the Night W[ind] NW
19 W[ind] E cold Accot wth Ch Jones gave him Noat
for his Ball[ance] after he had 2 qts rum
brot 6 bottles into the Closet
mr Stag my Son Robert came ovr the river
abt 12 I went to the Store 5 Lambs there
19 Ja Bryan begins abt Second Kill Cha Cleph[ans]
4 Calves at Old house 1 dyed last Night
12 at Indian Town 1 wthout a Damm
6 Calves at Changlins 16 lambs
6 Calves at Wolve [sic] house 7 Lambs was
8 1 died to day
3 Calves at Corotoman 8 Lambs
8 Calves at Hills 9 Lambs 42 Lambs at
home this day gave out a pd Coffee to Ma[tty]
Yesterday began to rub myself
This day was the first I see the Martins
This day I went to Captn Smiths mr
22 Gee went with me we began to
dig Trees & make holes
19 a warm morning Bunting the
new bricklayer went out a Sund[ay]
morn came not home till mond[ay]
in the Night I Charg Bunting for
this Elopmt 7/6 carrying away
my People wth him the Coachman
went away wth the spindle &c for Nom
iny came home in the Night——
22 149/15/11 Sterl my debt from Cook
makes Currency at 15 percent 172/5/[...]
Tho Sedden has bene 3 times with m[e since]
Xtmas from the falls by Land Ayed[? ...]
[Ma]r[ch] 24 1725 [sic]
had done Planting Trees at Old Plantat[ion]
l726
25 mr Gee went over the river Ja Withers
came here went away Saturday writ
to Savage Strother
Ja Thomas came here went away Satur
day sent my two Warrtss wth him
28 a fine morn I was very much Gript
last night had Eat some shift Bacon
Turnip Tops plentifully a wing of a C
hicken some Clary Pancake some
mytton drank sevl Glasses of madera
wine l glass Claret was in great
pain threw up some of my Victls
took E prop some Vol drops was
cold had my bed Warmd slept till
12 wakd very uneasie hot a low
quick Puls low spirits could hardly
breath read the book of Esther we
nt to Sleep after taking And[erson's] pills
slept till 7 wakt pretty Easie Cap
Gale went away at 12 my Physic
workt 4 times drank Coffee & gr[een]
Tee in the morn Eat stewd Mutt[on]
& bro [sic] at Dinner drank nothing
My brick kiln fired this morning
my Chimneys Swept
29 Captn WatkinSon arrivd in the Night brot
my Lettrs from mr Pemberton &c
30 Came mr Keith from Wmburg & Sam
Doctor Nicholas man from my Sons Lettrs given
me Accot of his wives delivery of a Son
31 Wind at SW blow so hard Keith cod
[n]ot go over the river I went to the brick house
[Apri]l 1 a fine day W[ind] at SW Keith went away
[...]ay half penny if he likes him he is
[to pa]y me 20£ for him by hnn Jansd [sic]
[began to write?] Lettrs I began to take Tincture of [word omitted]
yesterday
Ap[ri]l 2d 1726
rainey a Season At Night Shut up my
kiln of Bricks Mr Grimes came at Nigh[t]
wth the Govrs Lettrs I was very Ailing all day
a Sunday my Son Robt came home brot
me Lettrs from Eliot Lomax an Accot
of 3 Negros dead at Peumds End
4 mr Grimes major Fitzhugh Mr Carly wen[t]
away he pd me 10£ Cash towd his Qt Rents
Lawrence on Settling Accots paid me 11/10
I pd for Jno Tully 20s Sterl
I gave to Major Fitzhugh for Jno Warnr
a pistol[e] Captn Belfield came here I pd him
5 Majr Eskridg came here he promises to Settl[e]
an Accot with me & to pay me of in a little
time talks of a heavie hd Tobo to pay my Q Rents &c
6 a Cold day W[ind] W blew hard I went to the Hills
the Mill Buckles Wolf house Changlins India[n Town]
Orderd Pursell hands from 4 Quarters to
finish Gregorys Corn feild came home
after Sun Sett was terribly afflicted wth [word omitted] &c
7 a Cold morning W[ind] W I was somewt Easie[r]
slept well went to Denis Crowdr Blough poin[t]
11 hd at [Thomas] West 8 at Crowdr 4 at Denis
8 Gregory came home last [night] came from Coles
Point 26th ultimo was forct into St Marys
lay there [word omitted] daies brot home 3 Tubbs Buttr
Meeks Weight no 4.65.5.62.6:66 Old iron
239 lb. 104 bushels Salt a hd Beans a hd Peas 8—
fletches Bacon Cask Sydr 57 hds Tobbo.
the same day sent Gregory away aboard of Keiling
with a foresd Tobo & 9 hds more fryday night my
boat fetcht mr Staf ovr a Saturday he Taught here
10th Easter day mr Bell preachd an Excellt Serm[on]
the greatest Numbr of Communicants that
ever I saw my kiln fird the day before
11 very warn went to the Kiln met Gil Met
calf there my Sloop returnd from Keiling
12 a warm day prepare for town
13 I deliverd to Tho Berry two Noats Henr[y]
Rydr for 450 lb Tobo Jno Moreheads for [...]
Jo Gregory goes away for Fleets ba[y]
mr Berry promises 12m[pounds in ?] 12 h[ogsheads? ...]
be prizd 9 of them now 2 [ ...]
Ap[ri]l 15 1726
I carry to Town wth me Gold ---80/--/--
Spanish Sylvr 16/--/--
mild money 14/--/--
some Gold & Sylvr in my Pockt
This day dispatcht Hust, Connet Tob Pursel
Murphew. Bryan writ to Strother Ja Carter
Meeks sevl others
The Carter Arrivd the 17th Apl got to Anchoring
the 18
I was sick at Coll Pages till the 24 went to Town
on Monday 25th returnd to Coll Pages 6 May
got home the 9th at Night see another book
of Perticulars in my being abroad——
May 10 a fine day Ordd Washing my Sheep Put
on thinner Cloaths left of my wast Coat I went abd
th[e] Carter
11 I went to the earth digging at the Church Ordd Bun
ting away
I pd to Ge Yerby 40s on Accot of Tully by a
Noat on Captn Carter
12 I brot home wth me in my bag 10/12s Cur
2/12/6 mild money G [sic]
13 Gregory came home last Night brot 53 hds
of my Crops from falls 8 hds NB 8 hds HLee [sic]
I weighd all my own Tobb 8 hds Came ashor
2 from Red Oak of 3 damaged l from
Poplar damagd I took great heaps of dirt
out of the hd the red Oak Tobo wretched thin
pye bald Stuff cov'd with Yellow mold very
high Case
14 Jo Gregory came home from the Carter he
Carried 70 hds on board 8 HLee 8 do
NB 54 hds of my own Tobbo 40 markt
[tobacco mark] 14 markt [tobacco mark]
6 a rainey day Ralph Page Major
[E]skridg Captn Walls went away I recd
[fro]m Alexdr Hamiltons men 9 doz & l
[bo]ttles of Hock alias Rhenish [wine]
May 17 1726
Robin Christned his Daughter Eliza Godfathers
Charles Carter & Phi[llip] Smith Godmother[s] Eliza[beth]
Churchill Mary Carter I gave to mrs Falconar
the Midwife for Cha & Mary Carter a Pistol[e]
18 Cold Cloudy day wee have Planted & replan
ted most of or Crops
19 cold in the morning Sent my Mares away I went
aboard Captn Denton Agreed to Sell his Negros
I am to [sell?] Sixteen or 20 2[/] 3ds men at 20£ per h
ead I am
to draw 10 percent on the Sale for Commission to make good all
debts in this mannr if any of the Bills of Exce wil
not be pd the Protests are to be returnd to me
I am to give new bills for the Principal the
Protests to be mine he is to run into Coroto[man Creek]
there to lye for the Sale I am to be at no man
ner of Charge all to be Chargd to the Owner
21 I began the Sale 32 went of this day
23 sold 13:24th 11 in all 56 3 of them for Tobbo
Tho Berry ows me 5s Simon Salld ows me 40s Ster
I trust Gregory with a large Negro Girl he is
to give me his Bond to pay me Sixteen Pounds
Sterl with Interest till the money is paid
I trust to Tho Carter for 24s Sterling I am to
Stop so much out of his Crop.
24 I sold a boy to Wm Edwds a boy he pays 16£ for him
a Noat for 8/7s Sterling on mr Pain the rest to be
as followeth—
25 I set out for Town carry the following money
gold 16"15s Spanish 9 1/2 guineas in my Pocket som[e]
gold 33 Shillings Sylver, in the ginny Bagg 25£
currt money wanting 3s-15d
June 8 I got home at Night
9 Tully gives me Accot of Six Thousand foot Inch
& 1/4 Pine Plank sawd at mr Fleet in his wast
ground in his Corn feild 15 Trees 28 Stocks
10 My Sawyers & Tully goe away to Nomini
12 Sonday Tom Frost gets Burch Wills Money to tak[e]
a Boat Frost & Wills Launcht the Boat abord [a]
Barbadoes man they got drunk coming ash[ore]
Mooney Jumpt overboard sunk right dow[n]
& not seen any more
13 Monday Tho Frost lookt at the frame [but]
did no work Jno Grymes had Coll Page [...]
& Six Bottles came here from Maj Rob[inson ?]
June 14th 1726
Tho Frost not at work I went out wth my Sonn
Charles to all the home Qrs & to Kellys Coopers Eat my
Dinner at the brick house got home after Dark
15 was at the Mill blough Point Crowdrs Deniss'
got home after dark
16 a rainey day was at Church to hear a fun[era]l Sermon
no body there cleard up at Night
17 Jo Gregory came from the falls brot 22 hds
Crop Tobo1 from Harrolds 1 from Chews
1 from Skrines 7 from B Robinsons 17
from Peumds End 1 from Occupation
20 [double arrowhead] 1 Cask Peas from HB
lent Captn Denton a horse to Wiccocomoco
Let Cooks Children have some Lin[?] &c took
Bond of Edmunds Yerby Flower Setled wth poor
Sent Burch Manuel to Changlins, Single
Thorp Camble to the Indian Town
18 Gregory went aboard the Carter wth 54 hds
20 [tobacco mark] 23 [tobacco mark] 11 2 for the Secretary
Sold a Negro Girl to Barret for 2400 lb Tobb
21 Gregory goes his Voiage to Stafford was prodi[gi]
ous drunk when he went away we had a Vestry
this day for Appointing Counters
23 I go to Town carry with [me] 5 pistols 2 moydrs
a ddbloon [sic] 1/19 S in Sylver Captn Balls Captn
Lees Pistols for the Govrs Clerk
I lay at Coll Page that Night went to Town the 24th
in Compa with Grimes Randolph met in Coun
cil in the Capitol at 4 Clock sat till past Sun
Sett adjournd to Saturday morning the 25th abt
10 Clock Governr met us in the Council Chambr
Set till 3 adjournd to 6 met at the Govrs house
after Sun Sett Jennings Suspended the Governr
proposd this Currt half Years Salary for my
Ld Orkney & himself to be Signd by the Presid[ent]
[a]s usually designd to be don by Ordrs of Council
[O]pposd a great heat ensued [t]he Ordrs made
[...]se at ten Clock past at my Offering to take my
[...] he swore he was not gon yet he would Stay
[...] Consequence be what it would if his Do
[...] answered so we parted Sunday morn
June 26 1726
I prepared in the morning to Come away
Coaches readie come mr Grimes to me tells
me the Governr had sent for him when he returnd
told us we were Stopd the Governr wod have a Coun
cil monday morning to take of[f] Jennings Susp
ension after him comes Robinson Summons us
to be at Council next morning Expresses sent after Coll
Ludwell Coll Diggs to fetch them to this Council
Grimes & I had mighty disputes at last I took Coach
waited on theGovernr we soon came to a reconci[li]
alition of the termes the Summons were recd
& the Council were dischargd I took my leave
of the Governr & the Commissary we got to Coll
Pages abt 3 Clock I lay there that night came
from Coll Page 1/2 hour after 9 reacht Sealons
by 12 Machins by 3 got home at 6 the Pertic[ula]rs
of these Councils see in another place At
Town &c I paid away the following Sums
to mrs Syllavan a pistol I recd the Change
To the Govrs Clerk 3 pistols for Belfeild Ball Cha
Lee Sherifs Commissions
to Wilkinson in part pay for his Care of mr
Burwells Familys a ddbloon & pistol
£5/8/1 1/2
I gave money to mr Rand[olph ?] mr Holloway Coll Pages
Coachmen
27 I got home as before next day And till the
July 1st no remarkables Charles brot 4 Cows & Calves
from Tho Wests, 4 ditto from Denis Syllava[nt]s Doctr
Nicholas here he paid me 30S for Ja Whaley from
P Parkinson I deliverd m[r] Peryasons bill
July 2 Robin & his [family] went to Coll Wormleys he had
of me £5 Cash
4 I sent my boat to Coll Churchills for my
Daughter Mary Cha Coachman to Mill for Ind[ian]
5 I & my Son Charles went to Middlesex Court Alde[...]
paid me 2/5 Cash Seager promist me to meet
me at Lancastr Court & give me a new Bond
6 began to Write my Invoices finisht th[e]
Accot for the Jno & Betty took a Vomit of 25 G[rams]
Ypoco & 2 gr[ams] Tartar Em[etic] 2 Vomits spontan[eous]
2 more forct 5 Stooles had an Easie Night
7 Continued upon my Invoices pd to [Mr.]
Edgar £3 Cash
July 8 1726
bot 15 barrells Tarr 7 barrels Pitch paid 15S
for the Pitch 8S for the Tarr £ll/5/0
paid to Captn Smith for his Trees £10/12/--
I took ashore from mr Sinnot a pipe ofCaptn May
nards wine the price not Setled he askt 18£ Cash
I wod give but Sixteen he went away cald
at my house as he came down offerd to put
the pipe ashore & only take rect I consented
so took the pipe ashore writ to Captn Maynard
that I expected to pay but sixteen Pounds
9th
11 Lee Hamilton Pinkard went away writ to Coll
Lomax mr Strother to buy me some Salt of[f] the
Bermudas Sloop had an Examination of [?]ec
Jnoson Sarah Newton Lee Turberville bound
them over to Court
mrs Young told me her time was up she offers
to Stay till I can provide myself
Harry Quarry came in 20 Janr 1719 serves 2 yrs
6 months 3 weeks after his Indented time will be
free the 11th of Augst only Serving for the Canoa after
he brot me the Ordrs of Court from mr Edwds
At the old house Plants told by the Countey 125M
270[,000]
At Indian Town Counted 12600 & 12M Od hundd
15/11/3 Currency Gave Captn Denton my Exch
19th at Night my Sloop brot home no Sheets to the foresail
but 2 Oars to my flatt Mate Dove saies She had no
more
21 I let Ja Bryan have 35S
22 I recd G Hamiltons Exchange for 6/13/4 for my
Sloops carrying his Goods from Wiccocomo
Coll Page sends Sawny for my Boat
23 6 Clock Coll Ludwells Express came wth the Accot
of the Govrs Death after 2 the morning before
of a Pleurisie Dr Blair mr Holloway to take
Care of the Funeral appointed on Tuesday I
sent my Boat for Coll Page with L[udwell's] Lettrs
writ to L[udwell]. B[everley]. D[igges]. C[arter] of the Council also to
mr Robertson H. B—v took H Brents Exc[hange] 4S[...]
Doctor of [the] Carter dyed this morning my Sons
Express came 2 hours after Coll L[udwell]s I answered It by
[...] Messingrs
[Capt]n Graves came ashore staid till 28 I took
[bills of] Lading Settled an Accot 26 gave him
[...] 26th mr Rob[er]tson came here 25
July 27th 1726
25th writ to the Duke of New Castle Principa[l]
Secretary of State also to the Right Hon[ora]ble
the board of Trade & to Notifie the death
of the Governr &c See the Copys
gave to Odars Wife 20S
while mr Robertson was here appointed a Coun
cil to meet on Monday 1st of Augst he writ
Circular Lettrs to the Gent of the Council.
29 a great rain fell towds day Captn Mansel Tre
t] Trevi
sa in the Mansel arrivd here from Antega
Coll Armistead Major Churchil &c here Settl[ed]
an Accot wth Coll Armistead he paid me by
Debts due to Coll Berkley & himself from mr
Burwells Estate—
30 Saturday I went from home in Compa[ny] wth
Coll Page wee reacht his hous afore Sunsett
31 went to Church dined went to Wmburg
got there before Dusk went into Company
drank a bottle wine
Augst 1 very uneasie a great many Gent
came to see me Coll Ludwell did not come
at 2 Clock went to Council took the proper
Oaths Ordered a Proclamation to Continue
all in their Offices I gave the Council Dinnr
after Settled the Ceremonie of the funeral
Sent a Message by mr Holloway to Condole mrs
Drysdale to know how she did & to know
when she would allow herself to be visited
I would wait on her if she pleased
2d Wee mett in Council mr Grymes proposd
a Message of Condolance which was readily
agreed to be be Carried by mr H[olloway] & mr Bl[ai]r they
were Ordd to Acquaint her she was welcome
to Stay in the hous while her Occasions req
uired mr [Richard] Hickman was Ordd to take Care of
the house & Gardens when mrs Drysdale
left It The Funeral began at 3 the Council
had Gloves Rings & Scarfs the Council h[eld?]
up the Paul from the house to the [hearse ?]
then Walkt after to the Church thro the Militia the [...]
the Guns around while wee way to t[...]
Augst l726
2 when wee came to the Churchyd the Coffin
was taken out of the Hers the Council took hold
of the Paul and went by the Coffin to the body of
[the church] there [it] was Set wee went to or Pew mr Leineve
preacht the Sermon his Text 57 Isai 1st verse
perish & no man layeth it to heart merciful men &c
The righteous are taken away &c
Signd a Proclamation for Continuing all Officrs
in their Posts Signd 27 more afterwd Signd a
Lettr to the board of Trade to Accompa Duplicts
Signd sevl blanks Signd a Serifs Comn for Glostr
4 Visited mrs Drysdale she promist to deliver
mr Robertson all publiq Papers 5th Sent for my boys
saw mrs Stith &c
6 just as I [was] coming out of Town, mrs Drysdale sends me
a Lettr inclosing Sr Robt Walpoles Letters to Ld Ork
ney recommending Coll Drysdale to Succeed Coll
Spotswood also a Lettr from H[orace] Walpole to Coll Drus
desiring his Favor in behalf mr Lehoup to Succeed mr
Carter in the Agency of the Countrey I writ her a
Short Answer & came away lay at Coll Pages that
Money pd & given aw
Night & Sonday went to Church heard mr Richds his
Subject Sincerity or Simplicity the words And
Jesus saw Natha &c
8 Came to Coll Pag Seatons in Coll Pages Coach had his horses
to Rappa got home at Sunsett in Machens
Boat very sick at Night Doctor Nicholas came to
me at Ghants Swamp
Money I expended in my being out
mrs Sullivans Accot 8/1/6
paid to Hacker for Doctor Blair 3/8/3
to Ditto his Taylor Accot1/6/9
gave to Sue Cooper for Washing0/5/-
To mr H[olloway's] Coachman/2/6
To Mrs Syllevans Servts0/5/-
To Coll Pages Coachman0/2/6
To my boys abt0/4/-
To mrs Stiths Coachman0/1/3
To mr Claytons Tom0/1/3
Carried to Town 14/1/9
with me Gold 40/-/-
Cash Span[ish] 10/-/-
Beside what in my Pockett
[at ?] home in the Purse Gold——27/-/-
of Spanish money—— 8/-/-
[...] ket Spanish——2/1/6
[...] pistols 1 1/2 LewdOr
Augst 9th 1726
Began Cydr making the 3d of ths month Began Bric[k]
making the 4th of this month Richd Haines Begins
his Voiage to the falls the 1st of this month
The Carter Sailed from my house the 29 of Augst
July the 4 of July August she left the river Began
stilling the 3d of this month
10th went to Court swore to Cooks Inventory was very sick [at]
Night went to bed at 9 slept ill abt 2 hours then restles
all Night
11 began to take Doctor Nicholas Medicine after
1st doz very cheery eat heartily of Veal drank wine
freely Eat a small Suppr drank madera Whey
had a heavy Night slept abt 4 hours
12 took the Medicines again Purgd both daies
a very bad Night did not sleep a wink till daylt
Collo Pages Sawney came here brot the Instructions
mr Crew came here I Signd Lt Collo Robins Commission
& six Blanks writ to mr Holloway mr Robtson
pad 10S this day to Tho Carter on Accot of Tho Windr
my Boat both fetcht & Carried over mr Crew
18 was taken with a feavr & Ague mist it next day
20 had a violent fitt Ague very severe began 21th
to take the bark 4 first dows purgd me took Laud[anum]
no stool after till wednesday Night no more
fitts of the feavor
22 Signd my Will very uneasie
23 Coll Grimes came here 24 Setled an Accot wth him
25 mr Edwds went over the river writ by him to
mr Robertson
Richd Haines sett out for the Falls a fair wind
I gave to my Granddaughtr Ann Harrison Hannh['s]
Girl Alice my Daughtr Carrys her away wth
her
I also give to the Child my Daughter Harri
son now is ensient with Hannahs boy Aa
ron or in case of the death of such Child
to be born then to the next Child Son or
Daughter to be born of my sd Daughtr
Harrison Aaron stays behind my Dau[gh]tr
at this time until He is big enough t[o]
move
I give to my sd Daughtr 3 1/2 pistols 30 [...]
Septr 1 1726
the Secretary came hither I had the
Gripes took Hyera Picra It wrot severely
3 mr Grimes came here
4 I took manna wrot very much I continue
very bad
8 mr Robertson came here brot sevl Letters
from Spotsylvania Justices & Grayson
9 Metcalf here I sold 21 bushels wheat recd
3 Lewdeors 3/3/9 this Night Coll Ball
here
10 Secr[etar]y & Robtson went away My Daughtr came
here with her husband the 7th went away 16
Stag[g] here 16 Coll Ball was here last Saturday
18 B Churchill went away
mrs Young had Cash 10S8
24 mr Jno Guyn pays me 3£/8 Sterl[ing] & owes me
2£/3S/3d & his Quittrent for 2 y[ears] 1/12/-
Octor mr Gyyn sent me 2/3/3 the rent mr
Carter recd
Octor carry to Town Spanish Gold &c
In the bag——81/5/0
Majr Eskridg purs 16l/-/-
In my purse Span[is]h 13/5/-
Guyneas 2
in the bag d[itt]o 12 1/2 guinas
in the Guinea bag Spanish 9/8/-
Novr 9 I got home in the Night found Robt
Jones here met my Accots from Capt Hyde
10 agreed with Tim Stamps to be my
Overseer at Richland & Threlkild to
be Overseer at mr Burwells Quartr
at night came Tully & the Sawyers
brot an Accot of Goblin Jacks death &
of a boy named Tomboy I had many
Lettrs from the Falls hamton dead at
Pumd Inn, the Sloop brot 17 hds of my 2
wheat from Strother
[o]f them came before, 1 hd & 16 bushells
[fro]m Burwells Qr from Pumd Inn, 106 busls
the Sloop brot from Nomini 20 hds Sheld
[corn ?]01 bushells Salt 4 Tubbs butter Dicks
Novr 10 1726
Dick Qrs 82l Old Ordinary 80 Me[t]calfs 50
Brents Qrs 28l
15 My Sloop saild for the falls Scandret went by with
out calling
17 mr Bagg here I went to Corotoman &c very Sick twice
in the Night 3 daies ago Sent a Comm[issio]n into Staff[or]d
to h[an]g a Negro 2 daies since sent a Rev [sic] to Capt Jno
Jones agreed with Jno Williams for Poplar Hall wth
James Stark for Hulls Qr rid to Corotom[an] Wolf house Hills
18 rid to H Kelly Coopers brick house brewd Ale
19 rid to Denis Crowders Wests
21 a cold clear day a hard wind at West
22 my Sloop Ann Enterd into Captn Wilsons Em
ploy this morning
The Girl Ann died last Night
Meeks sends me Accots of 2 negros more
dead Gowen & Joan at D. Qrs
26 Stagg pay[s] me Currencey 17/11/11
he discots 2 pr Rump for GC 9/0
2 pr D[itt]o for Cartr Burwell 8/0
5 bottles Stoughton 6/3
————
recd 16/ 8/8
Novr: 30th: I Sent away for Rippon Hall the follow=
-ing Negroes, Tom from the Indian Town & Jenny his wife
Sambo. Judy his Wife and two Children—
Nick Reeds Joe his Wife Hannah and three Childn
The four Negroes that came from Cooks to with
Punch. Peter and the two women also the two Children
Charles the Joyner. The two Boys. Jemmy & Stephen
19 rid to Denis Crowders Wests
Also a white hand named John Tharp, All these
people were fresh Cloathd & found with bedding &c
Decemr 5 Capt Strother tells me there is in the
Sloop 9 1/2 barrels Corn & 4 Barrells to receive from
Skinker 52 bushls Wheat from Normans ford
5 bushels Sowd Thomas had 6 1/2 bushells
9 barrells Oxford had
7 Tubs & pots butter one half full poplar
Tallow 48l Richld 47l falls Qrs 70l Sewet & a[...]
Captn Strother gives the following Accot of the Crops
of Tob at the sevl Qrs Carters mount 6 prizd 7 to p[rize ?]
Normans ford 9 all prizd
Hinsons 7 prizd 2 to prize Red Oak—l0—5 [...]
Hall & 6 prizd 1 light
Richl[an]d 6—2 Park —9—[...]
Burwell 6—4 Poplar—14—[...]
86 hds all weighty & well handled [...]
Decr 7 1726
the six beevs from the falls at my Scales
weighd 2558 Tallow 138l lost of Stro[ther's]
weight 27l weight of the Butter as full
vessells & all 6 Tubs 28.38.38 55.72
71.75.pots 51.45.
W Edw[ar]ds brot home toll Cloth in 8 ps
59 3/4 yds
Young Dunlavy brot me toll Cloth in
7 ps 36 1/2 yds of sevl Sorts wch I allows
him for towd his fathers Debt at the rate
of 15 d Sterl per Yard
10 I go from home towd Town Carry 24£ in gold beside
the money in my Purse Mrs Young had 4£ gold & Sylvr
29 I got home, 21 Robin Carter went from home I let him [have]
5 pistols & 40S Currt money
Walker brot me 20 hogs from Dicks Qr Whaley brot me
11 from Old Ordinary Gibson brot 7 from Coles Point
22 Emelia came in I recd my Lettrs at Church Captn Law
rence drownd Captn Graves died some daies after he left
Virginia Major Gouch to be Governr
I agreed wth Morgan for Bridg & fork Qrs Whaley for old Ord[inary]
Pursel for Brents
23.24 fine Calm daies smart frosts at Night
my Sloop unlading her 2d Turn of wood
we have drawn in 160 Cart Load[s] wood beside round
wood
26 my Sloop went into [Captain] Bretts' Employ
28 comes D[uke] Newcastles mr Lehieus mr
Commissary &c Lettrs
I let Ed Kirk have 20S Cash
31 I had 2 Guineas from Capn Conway for
the Lawyers H[olloway] R[andolph].

div1.head: NOTES
div1.note: Source copy consulted: Robert Carter diary, 1722 - 1728, Robert Carter Papers (acc. no. 3807), Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia.
[1] Lawrence commanded the Princess Amelia. Carter would note in his diary concerning the ship's next voyage to the colony on 1726 December 22 that "Captn Lawrence drownd."
[2] Southam is a type of English ale.
[3] This footnote eliminated.

[4] Elizabeth (Armistead) Wormeley Churchill was Robert Carter's sister-in-law through her sister, his first wife. Judith Armistead. She married first Ralph Wormeley (1650-1701), and then William Churchill (1649/50-1710) of "Bushy Park," Middlesex County. Her daugher Priscilla married Robert Carter II.
[5] Captain William Keiling commanded the Betty. (Survey Report 6800, Virginia Colonial Records Project, Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia)

[6] A Captain John Cobb would command the Willis, a ship of 300 tons with 20 men, in 1727-28. (Survey Report 6801 on Adm. 68/194-5, ff. 4r, Virginia Colonial Records Project, Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia.)
[7] Captain John Steptoe lived on land that later (about 1778) would be known as Kilmarnock in Lancaster County. (B. Brainard Edmonds, Kilmarnock. [Kilmarnock, Va.: Little Pebble Press, 1976] 6.)

[8] The Piankatank River lies between the Rappahannock and York rivers and was the boundary in Carter's time between Middlesex and Gloucester counties (as it is today except that Mathews County has been cut off from Gloucester.
[9] This may be John Savage who was a surveyor, later (1734) to be employed by Lord Fairfax in his attempt to establish the boundaries of the proprietary. (Harrison. Landmarks. . . . p. 619.)

[10] "Thos. Edwards, a little petty Fogging Lawyer the Clark of our County that hath as much Mettle and more cunning for Contention then his predecessor had" Carter wrote to Landon Jones, July 23, 1723. Edwards was clerk of the Lancaster County court from 1720-1746. (Within the Court House at Lancaster. Lively, VA: Lively Printing Services, Lively, VA: Lively Printing Services, [1976]. p. 15.)

[11] Charles Grymes (c. 1692-1743) was the son of John Grymes of Middlesex County, but lived at "Morratico," Richmond County where he was sheriff, burgess, etc. ("The Grymes Family." Virginia Magazine of History and Biography. 28[1920]: 90-96, 187-94, 283-85, 374-75. and Ryland. Richmond County Virginia. . . . pp. 500, 504, 514.
[12] Carter means that he had an unruly, uncomfortable night.

[13] Alexander Scott (d. 1738), had received an M. A. degree from the University of Glasgow before coming to Virginia. He was the minister of Overwharton Parish, Stafford County, and a considerable land speculator. There are numerous references to him in Fairfax Harrison's Landmarks of Old Prince William.(Copeland and MacMaster. The Five George Masons. . . .p. 78; and Harrison. Landmarks. . . . pp. 146, 158, 200, 257, 284-85, 337, 665.)
[14] Philip Smith was sheriff of Northumberland County in 1723-1724. (McIlwaine. Executive Journals of the Council. . . ., 4[1721-1739]: 34,67.)

[15] John Stark was a merchant, probably the one to whom Carter referred when he wrote to Micajah Perry on1723 July 4 that he had drawn an order on "Mr. Stark of Glasgow." On that same day, he wrote to a John Stark, referring to Captain Bowman.
[16] Richard Haynes was master of one of Carter's sloops. (See Carter to Richard Meeks, 1729 June 30.)

[17] Captain Morrison may be Henry Morrison of Westmoreland County who was collector of customs on the South Potomac when he was appointed a justice of that county 1732 May 2. (McIlwaine. Executive Journals of the Council. . . ., 4[1721-1739]: 268.)

[18] Henry Lee (1691-1747) was a son of Carter's old friend, Hancock Kee (1653-1709). He lived in Westmoreland County at "Lee Hall" and married Mary Bland. (Burton J. Hendrick. The Lees of Virginia: Biography of a Family. [Boston: Little Brown, 1935]. pp. 329-30.)

[19] Old House Quarter was located in Christ Church Parish, Lancaster County, and was inherited by Carter from his brother. The name may refer to the original Carter settlement in the county. In Cater's 1732 inventory, George Conolly was the overseer there, managing 31 slaves, 116 sheep, 105 cattle, and "a horse calld Blackbird." ("Carter Papers: An Inventory. . . ."; Jones. John Carter II. . . . p. 55.; and Jones."Orders Book Entries . . . Referring to "Robert Carter. . . ." pp. 140-141.)
[20] Thomas West was the overseer at Blough Point Quarter in Northumberland County when Carter's inventory was prepared in 1732. (Carter Papers: An Inventory. . . .".)

[21] Thomas Woodward commanded the Providence during a number of voyages to the colony, 1723-1727. (Adm. 68/194 and 195, Virginia Colonial Records Project, Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia.)

[22] Landon Carter (1710-1778) was Carter's seventh child by his second wife, Elizabeth (Landon) Willis. Landon would live at "Sabine Hall," Richmond County, and marry three times, leaving many descendants, some of whom own "Sabine Hall" today. As an adult, he would keep a very interesting and useful diary. (Greene. The Diary of Colonel Landon Carter. . . .)

[23] John Falconar was a London merchant with whom Carter dealt. In 1728, Falconar and Henry Darnell would form an association of 29 London tobacco merchants to deal with the French tobacco purchasing agent as a group in order to keep the price as high as possible. The associaton lasted only lasted a year or two before dissolving because some of its members were dealing directly with the French agent and selling below the agreed-upon price. (Arthur Pierce Middleton. Tobacco Coast: A Maritime History of the Chesapeake Bay in the Colonial Era. Newport News, VA: Mariners' Museum, 1953. p. 129)

[24] There was a ferry over the Piankatank River near Berkeley Island operated by Bailey Seaton that Carter often refers to when describing trips to Williamsburg. There is a Seaton property noted on the Fry-Jefferson map on the Piankatank River in Gloucester County.
[25] A pistole was a Spanish gold coin in use in Carter's time.
[26] William Waugh (d. 1726) was an important overseer for Carter until his death in January 1726; he seems to have been in charge of Jackson's mill as well.
[27] Although Carter had an extensive collection of law books, none fits his description of "Turnrs Letters." (Wright. "The Literary Interests of the First Carters." )

[28] Charles Carter (1707-1764) was Robert Carter's tenth child; his mother was Carter's second wife, Elizabeth (Landon) Willis Carter. Charles would live at "Cleve," King George County, and inherit a number of properties in that area from his father. (Carleton. A Genealogy. . . of Robert Carter. . . . p. 340; and Morton. Robert Robert Carter of Nomini Hall. Numerous references.)

[29] John Wormeley (1689-1727), a younger son of Ralph Wormeley (d. 1701) for whom Carter had been a trustee in John's youth. When his older brother, Ralph died in 1714, John inherited all of their father's considerable estate in Middlesex and York counties. (See "Letters Concerning The Estate of Ralph Wormeley" in the opening page of this web site.)
[30] Ragged Point was a Westmoreland County farm probably located near the point of the same name. (Miller. Place-Names . . . . p. 131.)

[31] A James Bryan was listed as a resident of St. Mary's White Chapel Parish of Lancaster County in the 1716 tithable survey of the county. Carter agreed 1725 July 2 with a James Bryan "Brickmaker" for the production of 200,000 bricks. ("Tithables in Lancaster Co., 1716." William and Mary Quarterly 1st. ser., 21(July 1912): 111;and Carter diary, 1725 July 2.)
[32] A puncheon is a cask or barrel; John Tully was a cooper, a skilled tradesman who could produce barrels of various sizes.

[33] This was probably Barnabas Burch "the boatbuildr" with whom Carter had had problems before causing him to describe Burch as "an idle Roug ever Since he came here the work he has don hath not answerd" in his diary entry for 1725 February 2. In June of that year, Carter learned that Burch and several others had stolen a gun and hidden it in the woods. In July Carter won a judgement against Burch for running away, and because Burch confessed "that he is totally ignorant of and unable to perform the trade & misteries of a house carpenter for which he entered into Covenant with his sd Master in Great Britain." The court added time to Burch's indenture, and ordered that he receive no salary during his term. (Jones, Orders Book Entries . . . Referring to "Robert Carter. . . ." p. 120 page 181.)

[34] John Tarpley (1660-1739) was sheriff and a justice of the peace in Richmond County ("Second Generation" [of the Tarpley Family], http://freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.com/~natsgen/d1/i0000862.htm#i862, viewed 31/12/2002)
[35] John Shapley was made a justice in Northumberland County in 1725. (McIlwaine. Executive Journals of the Council. . . ., 4[1721-1739]: 82. )
[36] A chessel is a cheese vat.

[37] Blough (Bluff) Point plantation was in Northumberland County "on Jarvis Creek about four miles from Kilmarnock in Bluff Point Neck." Carter had purchased the property from "John Ludley, the Father and the Son . . ." and bequeathed it to Landon. (Miller. Place-Names . . . . . p. 82.; and Greene. The Diary of Colonel Landon Carter. . . ., p. 4.)

[38] Andrew Hutchinson was a member of the vestry of Truro Parish, Prince William County. In 1745, he would draw a deed to give land from his grant to the parish for a chapel on its western boundary but the chapel would not be built there because there was no water. (Harrison. Landmarks. . . . pp. 287-88.)
[39] Mrs. Young was Carter's housekeeper. He had agreed with her for one year's service in 1724 but found her satisfactory for a longer term.

[40] Carter noted in his diary on 1724 December 15 that he had agreed with Hugh Kelly as an overseer, and referred to the farm afterwards by Kelly's name. The location of the farm has not been identified.
[41] The Oxford English Dictionary does not include a meaning for this word.

[42] Constantine Cant was the captain of the Burwell. (Survey Report 6800 for Adm. 68/195, ff. 76v, Virginia Colonial Records Project, Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia.)
[43] Carter's will mentions land bought of William Rust in "Hartford County" up the branches of Bull Run, which joins the Occoquan River.

[44] George Mason III (c. 1690-1735), justice, sheriff, burgess, and county lieutenant of Stafford County, father of the constitutional theorist. (Copeland and MacMaster, The Five George Masons. pp. 50-86; and George Harrison Sanford King. The Register of Overwharton Parish Stafford County Virginia 1723-1758 And Sundry Historical and Genealogical Notes. [Fredericksburg, VA: privately printed, 1961.])

[44.1] Richard Talent (Galent) was one of Carter's indentured servants, probably a clerk as he was a witness to to codicils to Carter's will. Carter learned of his marriage in March 1726, and took the Talents into court where they "voluntarily acknowledged" a revision of their indenture for "further service." (Jones, Orders Book Entries . . . Referring to "Robert Carter. . . ." p. 196)

[45]"Anderson's Scots Pills, a product of the 1630's" had been invented by Patrick Anderson, a Scot, who wrote in a book published in 1635 that he had learned the secret of the pills in Venice. He passed the formula to his daughter Katherine who in turn passed it to a doctor named Thomas Weir in 1686. Weir obtained letters patent on the formula from James II in 1687. George B. Griffenhagen and James Harvey Young, "Old English Patent Medicines in America," in Contributions From the Museum of History and Technology (Washington, D.C.: Smithsonian Institution, 1959), paper 10, 156-183.)

[46] In the 1716 Lancaster County tithables list, a Thomas "Heanaugc" was listed in St. Mary's White Chapel Parish. ("Tithables in Lancaster Co., 1716." William and Mary Quarterly. 1st. ser., 21(July 1912): 109.)

[47] James Carter (1684-1743), of Stafford County, was the younger brother of Carter's dear friend and associate, Captain Thomas Carter of Lancaster County, and was one of Carter's chief managers. (Joseph Lyon Miller, "Captain Thomas Carter and His Descendants," William and Mary Quarterly. 1st ser., 17(1908-09): 275-285.)

[47.1] A ferry across the Rappahannock from Lancaster County was located at this Middlesex County property, probably owned by Thomas Machen who appears in the records of Christ Church Parish, Middlesex, in 1725. It was a short distance from Machens across the county to another ferry located at Seatons in Gloucester County on the south bank of the Piankatank River. Carter regularly took this route to Williamsburg. (Churchill Gibson Chamberlayne, editor. The Vestry Book of Christ Church Parish Middlesex County, Virginia 1663-1767. [Richmond: Old Dominion Press, 1927] p. 202.)

[48] In the court records, Richard and Elizabeth's last name is spelled "Galent." They bound themselves "for further service" as did Neal and Charles "Sullivan." (Jones, Orders Book Entries . . . Referring to "Robert Carter. . . ." p. 121 p. 196.)

[49] Anthony Dunlavy's son of the same name was bound until age twenty-one. His father was to teach him and "one Samuel Marshal another servant belonging to the sd Carter in the weavers trade." (Jones, Orders Book Entries . . . Referring to "Robert Carter. . . ." p. 121 pp. 197-98.)
[50] Wills' full name is found in Jones, Orders Book Entries . . . Referring to "Robert Carter. . . ." p. 121.

[51] Augustine Washington (1694-1743) was the father of George Washington, and a resident of Westmoreland County on Pope's Creek. He was a justice, sheriff, and vestryman. His second wife, Mary Ball, was the mother of George. (http://gwpapers.virginia.edu/faq/washbio.html [9/13/02], and Norris. Westmoreland County, Virginia. pp. 151-153.)

[52] Jack Ashley is mentioned a number of times in Carter's diary; he lived in Spotsylvania County and apparently was an overseer for Carter at one time although he does not appear in the 1732 Inventory. (McIlwaine, H. R., ed. Executive Journals of the Council. . . .. 4 [1721-1739]:254.)
[53] Captain Samuel Bowman commanded the Lucia. Carter also mentioned this vessel in his diary in June 1724.

[54] George Carter (ca. 1718-ca.1741-42) was Carter's fifteenth child; his mother was Betty Landon Willis Carter. He attended the College of William and Mary and was sent to London after his father's death to study law. He died there unmarried. (Carleton. A Genealogy. . . of Robert Carter. . . . p. 457.)
[55] The College of William and Mary.

[56] William Downman was a justice of Richmond County from 1718, sheriff in 1722 and 1723, and a tobacco inspector in 1731 and 1732. (Ryland. Richmond County Virginia. . . . p. 504; and McIlwaine. Executive Journals of the Council. . . ., 4[1721-1739]: 12, 34, 238, 286.)
[57] Denis was a farm close to "Corotoman" as Carter mentions it fairly often in his diary. Apparently its overseer was named Denis, and Carter refers to the farm by that name.
[58] Charles Jones was a long-time overseer for Carter at "Hills Quarter" in Lancaster County. Carter wrote to him there in 1727, and he appears in Carter's will as the overseer on that property.

[59] Carter mentions this property several times in his diary, but there are also references to the "Brick House store," and they may be the same property. In his will, Carter describes a tract in Lancaster County that he bought from John Bradley that lay next to the lands of the "brick store. " Also in the will he notes that the store "formerly belonging to the Estate of Mrs. Mary Swan Dec'd" was "under the care of Capt. Thos. Carter."

[60] In his will, Carter refers to the old plantation "bought of Mr. Robert Jones" in Northumberland County. In his inventory, Dennis Sullivant was the property's overseer of 8 slaves, 36 sheep, 75 hogs, 66 cattle, and "a Mare called Mopsy 10 yers old," etc. The property was bequeathed to Carter's son Landon. (Carter Papers: An Inventory. . . ."; and Greene. The Diary of Colonel Landon Carter. . . .p. 4.)

[61] James Withers (ca. 1680/1681-1746) had been born in England, probably in Bristol. He married Elizabeth Kenne and was a resident of Overwharton Parish, Stafford County where he died on1746 June 3.("The Wither Family (Withers, Wythers) Homepage " by S. Tweety. http://members.aol.com/DocSWatson/Witherindex.html. Checked 10/1/02.)

[62] The meaning of Carter's abbreviation, "E prop," has not been determined, but it was a form of medication, probably a purge, from his reference several lines below to his physic having "workt 4 times."
[63] Carter may mean vitriol drops, "a camphorated tincture of opium flavoured with aniseed and benzoic acid" according to the Oxford Englsih Dictionary.
[64] Watkinson was captain of the Vine, a ship that may have been owned by Micajah Perry. (Carter to Pemberton, 1724 March 25)

[65] Carter refers to the birth of his grandchild, George Nicholas (1726-1771), by his daughter Elizabeth (Carter) Burwell and her second husband, Dr. George Nicholas. (Carleton. A Genealogy. . . of Robert Carter. . . .p. 176.)
[66] This note eliminated.

[67] This mill, sometimes referred to by Carter as the small mill, was located in Lancaster County and may have been the one "on the head of the Eastern branch of Corotoman" purchased by Carter's brother John from Thomas and Elizabeth Haynes 1670 January 4. The property included about forty acres. (Jones, John Carter II. . . . p. 73.)

[68] "Corotoman," or "Buckles," was a property very close to Carter's home, also called "Corotoman." But this property was under the direction of an overseer named John Buckles, and Carter frequently refers to it as "Buckles."

[69] John Warner was the surveyor of King George County in 1727; he laid off the town of Falmouth in 1728. Later he worked for Lord Fairfax, and prepared an important map of his holdings. (Harrison, Landmarks of Old Prince William, 626-628.)

[70] Gibson's Plantation was a property located close to "Corotoman" in Lancaster County. Carter purchased 375 acres in 1703 from Edward Gibson, later adding 90 acres from adjacent property. In Carter's inventory, Ezericum Crowder was its overseer, and Carter sometimes refers to the property as "Crowders." (Sorrells.title>Landholders & Landholdings. p.18; and Carter Papers: An Inventory. . . ." Note revised 9/17/2007.
[71] St. Mary's was the Maryland county across the Rappahannock from Westmoreland County, Virginia, where Cole's Point plantation was located.
[72] A flitch is a side of cured meat, in this case, pork.
[73] Fleet's Bay is at the east end of Northumberland County not far from Corotoman.

[74] The child was Elizabeth Carter (1726-post 1763), the daughter of Robert Carter II (1704-1732) and his wife, Priscilla (Churchill) Carter (1705-1757). Elizabeth would marry in 1742 John Francis Willis of Gloucester County. (Carleton. A Genealogy. . . of Robert Carter. . . . p. 312.)
[75] Denton was commander of the John & Betty, a slave ship owned by John Pemberton, a Liverpool merchant. The ship would be lost in 1729. (See Carter to Pemberton, 1730 April 15.)

[76] Simon Sallard (d. 1747) was referred to in the 1732 inventory of Carter's property as "Mr." He was then the manager of the plantations in Richmond and Westmoreland counties, and the overseer of Brick House Quarter in Richmond County. ("Carter Papers: An Inventory. . . ."; Morton. Robert Robert Carter of Nomini Hall. p. 33; and Greene. The Diary of Colonel Landon Carter. . . . p. 304.)

[77] In 1723, the Assembly had passed an act limiting the quatities of tobacco produced in the colony. The vestries of each parish were required to take a count of all persons engaged in the production of tobacco and of the number of plants. (McIlwaine. Executive Journals of the Council. . . ., 4[1721-1739]:45-51; and Churchill Gibson Chamberlayne, editor. The Vestry Book of Christ Church Parish Middlesex County, Virginia 1663-1767. [Richmond: Old Dominion Press, 1927] p. 202.)

[78] Elias Edmunds appears in the 1716 tithables list of Lancaster County as a resident of Christ Church Parish. On 1726 June 8, George Flower and John Yerby were appointed as surveyors of roads in the county. ("Tithables in Lancaster Co., 1716." William and Mary Quarterly 1st. ser., 21[July 1912]: 107; and Jones, Orders Book Entries . . . Referring to "Robert Carter. . . ." p. 210.)
[79] Williamsburg.
[80] A moidore was a gold coin from Portugal or Brazil in use in Carter's time.

[81] Cole Digges (1692-1744) lived at "Bellfield" in York County. He was appointed to the Council in 1719. (McIlwaine. Executive Journals of the Council. . . ., 3[1705-1721]: 518, and Louis B. Wright and Marion Tinling, eds. William Byrd of Virginia: The London Diary (1717-1721) and Other Writings. [New York: Oxford University Press, 1958.] p. 459.)

[82] There is a Seaton property noted on the Fry-Jefferson map on the Piankatank in Gloucester County. There was a ferry over the Piankatank River near Berkeley Island operated by Bailey Seaton that Carter often refers to when describing trips to Williamsburg.
[83] Mrs. Sullivan ran the boarding house where Carter stayed while in Williamsburg.
[84] Charles Lee (1684-1735) of Cobb's Hall, Northumberland County.
[85] James Whaley was the overseer at the Westmoreland plantations Old Ordinary and Moon's Plantation in 1732. (Carter Papers: An Inventory. . . .")

[86] Given Carter's inventive and phonetic spelling, it is difficult to know what this word may be, but "ipecac" seems most likely as it is an emetic that had come into use in the previous century; it fits the context.

[87] Thomas Lee (1690-1750) was the son of Richard Lee II, and nephew of Edmund Jenings; he would build "Stratford," and succeed Carter on the Council. (Burton J. Hendrick. The Lees of Virginia: Biography of a Family. [Boston: Little Brown, 1935]. pp. 48, 51, etc.)

[88] On 1726 July 13, the Lancaster County Court found Abraham Johnson, his wife Ellinor, and Sarah Newton guilty of "having stolen several goods belonging to the Hon Robert Carter," and ordered all three to be whipped. (Jones, Orders Book Entries . . . Referring to "Robert Carter. . . ." p. 214. )

[89] John Turbervile (d. 1728) was a justice, burgess, and sheriff of Lancaster County. ("Tithables in Lancaster Co., 1716." William and Mary Quarterly 1st. ser., 21[July 1912]: 106-11; and "Turberville Family of VA," http://members.tripod.com/~Bonestwo/index-6.html, reviewed and downloaded 10/31/2002 )

[90] Thomas Pelham-Holles, the 1st Duke of Newcastle, was Secretary of State in the Walpole government; Richard L. Morton notes that the duke carried on a policy of "`saluatory neglect' of the colonies which lasted until the Seven Years' War." (Morton. Colonial Virginia. p. 506.)
[91] Carter refers to his sons Landon and George who were students at the College of William and Mary in Williamsburg.

[92] Reverend William Le Neve had been the minister of James City Parish since 1722. (William Meade, Bishop. Old Churches, Ministers and Families of Virginia. [Philadelphia: J.B. Lippincott Company, 1900]. 2 vols. 1:94.)
[93] Alexander Spotswood (1646-1740) had been the governor from 1710 to 1722.

[94] Horace Walpole was the brother of Robert Walpole, the chief minister of England. He held the posts of "auditor general and surveyor general of the royal revenue in the colonies." (Billings. et al. Colonial Virginia: A History. )

[95] Peter Leheup, an English Treasury clerk, was Virginia's and other colonies' agent in England for some years. He was related by marriage to the Prime Minister's brother who was secretary of the Treasury. His influence would be greater near the end of Carter's life. (Price. Perry of London. . . . pp. 75-77, 80, 83.)

[96] Reverend John Richards (d. 1735) had been born in England where he was rector of various parishes. After coming to Virginia, he was rector of Ware Parish, Gloucester County. (William Meade, Bishop. Old Churches, Ministers and Families of Virginia. [Philadelphia: J.B. Lippincott Company, 1900]. 2 vols. 1:328, 354.)

[97] Carter had testified in court on 1726 January 27 that John Cook(e) had died intestate, and he had been appointed administrator of the estate as Cook's "greatest creditor." (Jones, Orders Book Entries . . . Referring to "Robert Carter. . . ." pp. 210 and 215.)

[98] Anne (Harrison) Randolph (ca. 1722-1745) was Carter's granddaughter by his daughter Anne and her husband, Benjamin Harrison IV. She would marry William Randolph of "Wilton," Henrico County in 1735. ("Harrison of James River," Virginia Magazine of History and Biography. 32(1924): 97; and Carleton. A Genealogy. . . of Robert Carter. . . . p. 254.)
[99] Enseint means pregnant.

[100] According to the "On-Line Medical Dictionary" hierapicra is "a warming cathartic medicine, made of aloes and canella bark." ("On-Line Medical Dictionary" at http://cancerweb.ncl.ac.uk/omd/ as of 12/20/2002.)

[101] The Oxford English Dictionary defines manna as a "sweet pale yellow or whitish concrete juice obtained from incisions in the bark of the Manna-ash, Fraxinus Ornus, chiefly in Calabria and Sicily; used in medicine as a gentle laxative. Also, a similar exudation obtained from other plants."
[102] Carter means the French coins, louis d'ors.

[103] Robert Jones was the son of William Jones of Northumberland County but he moved to Prince William County where he was a justice and sheriff, 1731-32. He was a head overseer for Carter in the upper country between 1727 and 1729. (Harrison. Landmarks. . . . p. 339; and Berkeley. "Robert Carter as Agricultural Administrator: . . .", 273-295.)
[104] A William Threalkill was the overseer at Poplar Quarter in Stafford County in the 1732 inventory of Carter's estates.("Carter Papers: An Inventory. . . .")
[105] Dick's Quarter was located in Westmoreland County; John Walker was the overseer of 23 slaves, 2 horses, 19 hogs, and 41 cattle in 1732. ("Carter Papers: An Inventory. . . .")

[106] Metcalfs was a farm in Westmoreland County. In 1732, John Ordra was the overseer of 5 slaves, 3 horses, 10 sheep, 40 hogs, and 47 cattle. The property descended to Robert Carter III together with Brents Quarter. The two properties comprised 1932 acres. (Carter Papers: An Inventory. . . ." and Morton. Robert Robert Carter of Nomini Hall. p. 70.)

[107] Brents Quarter lay in Westmoreland County. In the 1732 inventory of Carter's property, the overseer was Murphy Brand who worked 23 slaves and had 49 hogs and 56 cattle on the place. The property descended to Robert Carter III together with Metcalfs Quarter. The two properties comprised 1932 acres. (Carter Papers: An Inventory. . . ." and Morton. Robert Robert Carter of Nomini Hall. p. 70.)
[108] Halls was a farm near the falls of the Rappahannock.

[109] Carter Burwell (1716-1756) was Robert Carter's grandson by his daughter Elizabeth (Carter) Burwell and her first husband, Nathaniel Burwell (1680-1721). Carter Burwell would live at "Carter's Grove," and would marry Lucy Grymes in 1738. (Carleton. A Genealogy. . . of Robert Carter. . . . p. 128.)
[110] The handwriting in the diary changes at this point; it is no longer Carter's but that of one of his clerks. All the text not in Carter's hand is indicated by the use of bold lettering.

[111] Rippon Hall was Edmund Jening's estate in York County which he had acquired in 1687 from John and Unity West when it was named "Poplar Neck." Jenings's bad financial circumstances forced him to mortgage the property to Carter who eventually acquired title to it. ("Notes and Queries." William and Mary Quarterly. 2[Apr. 1894]: 270-278.)
[112] Roger Oxford was the overseer at Norman's Ford.

[113] This farm lay either in Richmond or Westmoreland County. Mary R. Miller attributes it to Richmond. In Carter's 1732 inventory, William Crane was its overseer, supervising 12 slaves, 2 horses, 18 hogs, and 29 cattle. (Miller. Place-Names . . . . p. 67; and "Carter Papers: An Inventory. . . .")

[114] Carter may have been attempting to spell "tow" in his usual idiosyncratic phonetic way. "Tow is coarse flax (linen) material made with the short fibers of flax left in the hetchel, or combing device. It is a type of cloth that would have been woven on any plantation that was producing flax, as tow is a good way to use up the by-products of linen production." (Linda Baumgarten, Curator of Textiles and Costumes, Colonial Williamsburg, in an email to the editor, 2002 December 30.)
[115] According to the 1732 inventory of Carter's estate, John Walker was the overseer at Dick's Quarter of 23 slaves, 2 horses, 19 hogs, and 41 cattle. ("Carter Papers: An Inventory. . . .")

[116] The Princess Amelia was a Weymouth ship that may have been owned by Edward Tucker. She had been commanded by a Captain Lawrence who, as Carter notes, had been drowned. A John Brett was her captain as of 1726 November 10. (Weymouth Port Books described in Survey Report 9729, Virginia Colonial Records Project, Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia.)

[117] Bridge House Quarter was located in Richmond County and lay close to Hickory Thicket "northeast of Warsaw." In Carter's 1732 inventory, Charles Campbell was the overseer of 9 slaves, 8 horses, 41 hogs, and 31 cattle. (Miller. Place-Names . . . . p. 16; and "Carter Papers: An Inventory. . . .")

[118] This may be Francis Conway of Essex County who would be one of the first justices of Caroline County when it was formed in 1728. (McIlwaine. Executive Journals of the Council. . . ., 4[1721-1739]:172. )
